question_text:
Read this sentence from paragraph 1.

 The scene is like a twisted . . . movie, with doomed gadgets riding an unrelenting conveyor belt into a machine that shreds them into piles of copper, aluminum and steel.

The words “twisted,” “doomed,” and “unrelenting” most affect the sentence by
options: emphasizing that discarded devices are condemned to an unfortunate fate.
expressing a sense of desperation about the amount of waste from discarded devices.
implying that discarded devices are often disposed of in an inappropriate manner.
suggesting a feeling of doubt about solving the problem of discarded devices.

question_text: How does paragraph 2 build on what the reader learns in paragraph 1?
options: Paragraph 2 explains the underlying cause of the massive amounts of recycling that are described in paragraph 1.
Paragraph 2 discusses the past trends that have led to the technological innovation mentioned in paragraph 1.
Paragraph 2 cites statistics that support the claim about technology that is stated at the beginning of paragraph 1.
Paragraph 2 expresses disapproval of the consumers who throw away the products that are discussed in paragraph 1.

question_text: Which sentence from the excerpt suggests that electronic devices are purposely designed to be disposed of after a short time?
options: “ ‘In our society, we always have to have the new, best product,’ said Aaron Blum, the co- founder and chief operating officer of ERI, on a tour of the facility.” (paragraph 2)
“Even when e- waste rules exist, it’s left up to consumers to handle their old devices properly.” (paragraph 6)

“Most smartphone batteries can’t be easily replaced when they stop holding a charge, new laptops don’t accept old cables, and software companies push upgrades that won’t run on old devices.” (paragraph 7)
“Some environmental groups say multibillion- dollar companies . . . should pick up the cost of recycling the devices they sell.” (paragraph 8)

question_text: IThe details in paragraphs 4–5 develop a central idea of the excerpt mainly by suggesting that
options: the toxic components of e-waste make waste collectors reluctant to process electronic devices.
communities across the nation have taken different approaches to the management of e-waste.
increased amounts of e-waste will further intensify a problem that is already inadequately addressed.
the methods that are used for disposing of non-electronic waste are inefficient for e-waste.

question_text: What is the role of paragraphs 7– 9 in the organization of the excerpt?
options: They emphasize the contrast between successful and unsuccessful efforts to regulate electronic waste.
They suggest that the electronic devices that were manufactured in the past created less pollution.
They imply that manufacturers are willing to comply with regulations that protect the environment.
They shift the focus from a discussion of individual behavior to a discussion of corporate responsibility.

question_text: The idea that e-waste regulations can be ineffective is conveyed in the excerpt through
options: a statistic indicating that only a few states have chosen to adopt e- waste regulations.
an observation about typical consumer behavior in response to e- waste regulations.
an acknowledgment that electronics stores sometimes profit from e- waste regulations.
a comment that manufacturers are making an effort to recycle even without e- waste regulations.

question_text: How does the diagram after paragraph 9 most support the claim made in paragraph 4?
options: The diagram suggests that people send large amounts of recyclable e- waste to landfills.
The diagram emphasizes that toxic chemicals in e- waste can easily spread from landfills.
The diagram implies that most landfills are poorly designed to accommodate e- waste.
The diagram shows that water sources near landfills are endangered by e- waste.

question_text: In paragraph 3, the phrase “the butterflies of the sea” conveys the idea that
options: nudibranchs do not have to work as hard as other animals to survive in the ocean.
nudibranchs have colorful features that make them stand out.
nudibranchs are delicate and have trouble adapting to their environment.
nudibranchs are rare and difficult to find in the ocean.

question_text:
Read these sentences from paragraph 4.

 I’m not sure why I decided to take a look. It was still an hour before sunrise, and I knew exactly what the bars looked like in the moonlight, but for some reason, I couldn’t resist.

The sentences contribute to the overall structure of the excerpt by
options: introducing the mysterious creature that the narrator discovers.
indicating a shift from the narrator recalling the past to the narrator reflecting on the present.
establishing a struggle with fear that the narrator must overcome.
building tension through indicating that the narrator is going to see something unexpected.

question_text: Which sentence from paragraph 5 supports the idea that the narrator is taking a risk?
options: “It was an exhale, a release of sorts, and I instantly wondered if a whale was stranded again.”
“I looked for a hulking silhouette but couldn’t find one.”
“I waited, but there were no more sounds.”
“I knew the flats well enough to know I could get stuck just about anywhere.”

question_text:
Read this sentence from paragraph 6.

I kept stepping toward the one sound I’d heard, a growing part of me hoping I’d find nothing at all.

How do the narrator’s actions develop a central idea of the excerpt?
options: The narrator’s concern about the origin of the noise shows dedication to helping preserve sea life in the mudflats.
The narrator’s curiosity about the sea life in the mudflats outweighs any fear about the situation.
The narrator’s knowledge about a variety of sea life encourages a search for more specimens to study.
The narrator’s eagerness about new specimens of sea life outweighs the reality that the area is an unlikely place to find them.

question_text:
Read these sentences from paragraph 8.

So, I was looking at it and not looking at it while my heart spangled my vision. I saw fragments, pieces, and tried to fuse them in my mind but couldn’t be certain of the whole.

The sensory language “spangled my vision,” “I saw fragments, pieces,” and “tried to fuse them in my mind” conveys the narrator’s
options: extreme excitement about making a great discovery.
reluctant acceptance that he needs to leave the mudflats.
terrified confusion about the creature in the mudflats.
sudden concern about his personal safety.

question_text: The author develops the narrator’s point of view when the narrator sees the creature by
options: describing the narrator’s movements as he approaches the creature.
emphasizing the odds of finding the creature in an area inhabited by a rival species.
showing the narrator’s growing realization of the creature’s identity.
comparing the size of the creature to the size of a vehicle.

question_text: How does the setting affect the plot of the excerpt?
options: The darkness of the mudflats before sunrise causes the narrator to pay close attention to his surroundings.
The rugged terrain of the mudflats makes it more difficult for the narrator to do his job.
The slow return of the tide along the mudflats forces the narrator to be patient during his journey.
The barren appearance of the mudflats creates a sense of mystery that unsettles the narrator.

question_text: The phrases “166,000 floating solar panels are strung together atop the rippling surface of a lake” and “an immense blanket of renewable energy” in paragraph 1 convey that the solarpower farm
options: produces the maximum amount of energy possible for its size.
meets and exceeds the energy needs of the area.
blends in with the surrounding landscape.
produces a large amount of energy and is in an unusual location.

question_text: The author includes the statements from Dajie in paragraphs 2 and 7 most likely to
options: prove that the solar- energy industry benefits the economy of China by providing jobs.
provide the reasons why traditional energy sources are being replaced with solar-power farms.
highlight how replacing fossil fuels with solar energy offers more than just financial benefits.
argue that additional solar- power farms should be built in the Anhui province.

question_text: How does paragraph 2 contribute to the development of ideas in the article?
options: It explains the series of events that led a former coal miner to become an electrician at a solar-power farm.
It provides details on how a shift from coal mining to collecting solar power can improve conditions for energy workers and the environment.
It describes the reasons a company chose to transform a lake created by a collapsed coal mine into a solar- power farm that floats on the water.
It presents an overview of how a collapsed coal mine became a productive floating solarpower farm over several years.

question_text: Which statement best describes how the chronological structure of paragraphs 4– 5 contributes to the development of ideas in the article?
options: It reveals how China’s businesses lowered the cost of solar energy over time for other countries.
It depicts how China’s government helped the Chinese solar- energy industry respond to growth in the international demand for solar energy.
It reveals how China’s position on using solar energy changed because of a surplus supply of solar panels.
It depicts how China’s solar- energy industry improved the manufacturing of solar panels in order to increase revenue.

question_text: How do the details in paragraph 6 about the solar- power goals of the Chinese government convey a central idea of the article?
options: They indicate that the Chinese government wants China to be the world leader in solar energy production.
They show that the Chinese government understands the benefits of transitioning to renewable energy sources such as solar power.
They suggest that constructing solar- power farms is the best way for the Chinese government to put excess solar panels to use.
They imply that solar farms are a good way for the Chinese government to make solar power the main source of energy in China.

question_text: China’s role in the increase of solar- energy use around the world is illustrated in the article mainly through the inclusion of
options: information about where Chinese businesses sold solar panels and other materials for solar- power farms.
explanations of how solar- power use in China demonstrated that solar power could replace other energy sources.
details about how the Chinese government encouraged its citizens to use solar energy.
facts indicating that Chinese manufacturing processes helped make solar power more affordable.

question_text: The author’s purpose for writing the article is best conveyed by the
options: information about the positive outcomes China has achieved by producing renewable energy.
facts about how China has influenced other countries to use solar power as a source of renewable energy.
statements that present solar power as one of several forms of energy used throughout China.
details that emphasize how China developed its solar- power industry primarily as a means of financial gain

question_text: How do the details in paragraph 4 about Germany, Spain, and Italy contribute to a central idea of the article?
options: They indicate why businesses in China worked to become proficient producers of solar panels.
They emphasize the global need for solar power as a source of renewable energy.
They reveal that European countries were competing to see which country could reach its renewable- energy goals first.
They suggest that other countries viewed China as a model for constructing solar- power farms in unlikely places.

question_text: How does the author’s use of comparison in paragraphs 4 and 5 contribute to the development of ideas in the excerpt?
options: It identifies why many adults are never able to learn a second language.
It demonstrates why the study of adult language learning tries to include physical activity.
It highlights why more is known about language learning in children than about language learning in adults.
It explains why adults were the subjects of the study rather than children.

question_text:
Read this sentence from paragraph 6.

To see what effects exercise might have on this process, the researchers first recruited 40 college- age Chinese men and women who were trying to learn English.

Which statement describes the function of the sentence in the overall structure of the excerpt?
options: It indicates a shift from describing the results of the study to describing the process.
It introduces the aspect of the research that was most critical to determining the results.
It marks the change from explaining why the study was conducted to explaining how the study was conducted.
It shows how questions were raised that could be addressed in further research.

question_text: In the study described in the excerpt, researchers asked English learners to assess the sense of words in context because that task is
options: better at determining the capability learners have of language than simple vocabulary recall.
consistent with the way earlier research was conducted on adult language learners.
a better way for learners to absorb the meaning of individual vocabulary words.
more difficult for learners to perform after an extended period of time has passed.

question_text: Which evidence from the excerpt is most relevant to the author’s claim that there are many unanswered questions about the relationship between movement and learning?
options: the method of the study using one type of exercise and people from one age group
the statement from Dr. Sulpizio explaining past studies on neurochemicals in the brain
the finding of the study that exercise helps people recall information over a long period of time
the statement from Dr. Sulpizio describing how the results of the study can be applied

question_text:
Read these sentences from paragraph 17.

 These improvements extend beyond simply aiding in memorization, she added. The exercise also deepened language learners’ grasp of how to use their newly acquired words.

 Which sentence from the excerpt best explains why Dr. Sulpizio feels confident in the conclusion stated in these sentences?
options: “They were shown 40 words per session, with the sequence repeated several times.”(paragraph 10)
“They also responded to sentences using the new words, marking whether the sentences were accurate or, in the case of ‘The apple is a dentist,’ nonsensical.” (paragraph 11)
“And at the end of each lesson, the students who had ridden bikes performed better on the subsequent vocabulary tests than did the students who sat still.” (paragraph 13)
“They also became more proficient at recognizing proper sentences than the sedentary students, although that difference did not emerge until after several weeks of instruction.”(paragraph 14)

question_text: Paragraph 18 shows that the author’s perspective toward the study described in the excerpt is that
options: though the study allowed some conclusions to be drawn, these conclusions are limited.
while the study focused on moderate exercise, it would have been better to focus on difficult exercise..
while the study was performed appropriately, it is doubtful the results can be duplicated.
though the study was about learning language, its conclusions can be applied to learning in general.

question_text: Which sentence is the best summary of the research procedure used in the study in the excerpt?
options: Researchers had a group of non- English- speaking students learn new English vocabulary by matching words and images on a computer screen, and also by analyzing words in context; some students exercised and some students sat still while learning.

Researchers first divided non- English- speaking students into two groups with one group exercising before and while studying English and the other group studying English without exercising; then, after instruction, student learning was assessed.

Researchers first had non- English- speaking students sit on stationary bikes and pedal for 20 minutes before instruction and 15 minutes during instruction; then, after a rest period, students indicated whether English sentences made sense.

Researchers asked non- English- speaking students to study English while sitting or biking; then the students’ vocabulary skills were assessed after a short break period and also after a break of a full month without their having studied any of the materials.

question_text:
Read lines 5– 8 from the poem.

So beneath the level of molecules are atoms,
and beneath the level of atoms, we find
protons, electrons, neutrons; and beneath that—
what, exactly?

The lines help develop a central idea of the poem by revealing the speaker’s
options: interest in determining how the parts of matter work together
curiosity about what makes up matter.
desire to prove that particles make up matter.
questions about what tools are needed to study matter.

question_text: The break between the second stanza (lines 5– 14) and the third stanza (lines 15– 26) serves as a transition from
options: identifying common physical objects to explaining how the particles that make up all physical things are observed.
suggesting that the visible world is made up of simple materials to revealing why invisible materials make the world complicated.
discussing the methods used to study particles in space to describing how matter is researched on Earth.
describing an environment that feels comfortable to characterizing an environment that seems unstable.

question_text: The main purpose of the comparison in lines 23– 24 of the poem is to show
options: that the particles’ size makes them difficult to see.
how the particles move within the tunnel.
that the particles have a familiar shape.
how the particles can be seen only in darkness.

question_text:
Read lines 25– 26 from the poem.

until everything we think we know
bangs against everything else we know.

The lines help develop a central idea in the poem by suggesting that
options: creative methods for researching particles are frequently being invented.
ongoing research continues to add to our knowledge of particles.
our understanding of particles is limited by the equipment available to study them.
competing theories about particles provoke scientific debate.

question_text:
Read lines 27– 28 from the poem.

And there, in the explosion, in the darkness,
briefly incandescent, they appear:

The imagery in the lines reveals that the speaker
options: envies the physicists who research colliding particles.
has personally observed colliding particles.
admires the powerful reactions that occur when particles collide.
has a simplistic understanding of how particles collide.

question_text:
Read lines 30– 32 from the poem.

Their names
sound like dinosaurs or maybe bands
playing terrible music in someone’s garage.

The speaker refers to familiar objects and events in the lines most likely to
options: explain confusing information in simple terms to help the reader understand more about the topic.
demonstrate how scientific ideas can be explained by describing situations that many people are familiar with.
emphasize that the process being used to research particles is still in the early stages of development.
suggest that the scientific language used to describe particles seems silly by making a humorous comparison.

question_text:
Read lines 36– 39 from the poem.

both together and apart, what keeps
together the pencil in your hand right now
as well as separate from, say,
Jupiter.

The poet includes these lines most likely to emphasize that
options: it is important for physicists to continue their research about particles.
these particles have a powerful effect on everything.
the discoveries about particles provide little information.
the study of particles and the study of objects in space are similar.

question_text: The last stanza (lines 33– 44) concludes the poem by emphasizing which central idea?
options: The exciting work that physicists conduct provides information about fundamental aspects of the universe.
The unusual work of physicists is carried out in unconventional locations and in special conditions.
Physicists are learning about the unpredictable behavior of particles that break up matter in the universe.
Physicists enthusiastically share the discoveries their research yields because most people can relate to their findings.

question_text:
Read lines 39–44 from the poem.

They spin, and it is only down there
in the darkness— in the vast garage
where physicists jot down
what they can, whatever seems most real—
that they let us perceive their wild dancing,
combusting to the music they make.

The lines reveal the speaker’s
options: frustration with the research facilities physicists use.
belief that physicists are frantically working toward a new discovery.
interest in physicists and their study of particles.
certainty that physicists are working in secrecy.

question_text: In paragraph 1, the phrases “cool morning breezes swept freely” and “wafting the perfume of sweet grasses” affect the tone of the excerpt by suggesting
options: the sadness that the author feels reflecting upon her former way of life.
the enthusiasm with which the author approached her work indoors.
the fond feelings that the author has toward her childhood experiences.
the mix of emotions that the author feels toward her work and her mother.

question_text: The phrase “just as an artist arranges the paints upon his palette” in paragraph 2 suggests that
options: beadwork is a true form of art.
color is a source of artistic inspiration.
all artistic activities begin with a series of steps
the beadworker tries to imitate art.

question_text: The author’s use of sequence in paragraphs 1 and 2 contributes to the development of ideas in the excerpt by
options: listing the many steps that are involved in the process of beading in order to explain its difficulty and complexity.
conveying the importance of following the steps of the beading process in a precise order to work most efficiently.
emphasizing the time required to fully prepare for and execute the many large and small tasks in the activity of beading.
detailing each step in preparation for beading in order to highlight the author’s enthusiasm for the work.

question_text: The details in paragraph 3 convey a central idea of the excerpt by suggesting that
options: the author was interested in the work because she knew her mother was making something for her.
the author had difficulty learning through observation but wanted to help her mother.
the author was determined to behave according to her mother’s standards and sought her approval.
the author had great admiration for her mother’s precision and mastery of her craft

question_text: Which sentence best summarizes the process of beading that is described in the excerpt?
options: Take a buckskin bag full of beads and spread them out on a mat in different colors like a paint palette; take a double sheet of buckskin and smooth it out on a table; take a sinew and awl and thread the beads onto the buckskin in a desired pattern.

Cut the double sheet of buckskin into a shape; take a skein of sinew and pierce the buckskin with an awl; thread the sinew with beads of many different colors in a simple or complex pattern; twist the sinew to keep it tight after every stitch into the buckskin.

Arrange the beads into groups of colors on a mat; smooth out a double sheet of buckskin and cut it to shape; take a single thread of sinew; pierce the buckskin with an awl; thread the buckskin with the sinew and string it with beads, carefully twisting after every stitch.

Gather beads, buckskin, sinew, and awl and place them on a mat; cut the buckskin into the desired shape; decide on a pattern for the beads and create it using the sinews and the awl; thread the beads onto the sinew in the desired pattern and twist it tight.

question_text: The idea that mastering moccasin design and creation requires experience is best illustrated in the excerpt through
options: the information about the advanced technique of incorporating porcupine quills into a design.
the descriptions of the special materials that must be used to make decorated moccasins.
the descriptions of the various color combinations that make an attractive moccasin design.
the example of the author successfully and independently using a sharpened rod.

question_text: How does the author distinguish her point of view from that of her mother?
options: by describing their techniques for knotting sinew thread (paragraph 4)
by describing their approaches to beadwork design (paragraph 5)
by stating her mother’s instructions on working with quills (paragraph 6)
by stating her mother’s ideas about activities after lessons (paragraph 7)

question_text:
Read this sentence from paragraph 7.

Always after these confining lessons I was wild with surplus spirits, and found joyous relief in running loose in the open again.

Which sentence best describes how this sentence fits into the overall structure of the excerpt?
options: It introduces a shift from the author’s demanding relationship with her mother to her more relaxed relationships with friends.
It signals a change from the challenging aspects of life on the reservation to the advantages of living on the prairie.
It highlights a contrast between the focus and control required while working and the freedom of having fun outside.
It concludes the progression of events in the narrative by describing the sequence of events at the end of the author’s day.

question_text: The table after paragraph 7 expands upon a central idea in the excerpt because it shows that
options: the craft that the author was learning was a tradition that endured through many generations and changes.
the author’s family incorporated traditional materials into their craft as a way of resisting the influence from European traders.
the uniqueness of the cultural tradition that the author learned as a child was eventually recognized in Europe.
the author was able to incorporate color into her craftwork as a result of trade with other peoples.

passage:
(1) There is considerable scientific debate over the effects of screen-based technology on the brain. (2) In addition, there are political disagreements over how much regulation should be applied to such media.

 (3 ) In general, computer usage seems to be most positively associated with improvements related to quick and basic information processing. (4) For example, people who play certain computer games are often better at performing tasks that require processing visual information quickly. (5) These games also help people develop improved reaction times and a better ability to shift focus between tasks.

 (6) Computer use can also improve our ability to learn. (7) For example, playing certain educational video games can increase students' interest in certain subjects. (8) Students also learn better when they are actively engaged in a task. (9) When they play math games online as part of their studying, they are more likely to master the skills they learn in school.

 (10) However, people should not conclude that playing computer games makes people smarter. (11) In addition, improved skills in one area are not transferable to improvements in other areas. (12) For example, improved visual-spatial skills will not make someone better at math. (13) Not only does computer use not make you "smarter" in the most fundamental sense, but excessive computer use can also reduce cortical thickness of the brain and have impaired cognitive functioning. (14) Computer addiction is often caused by anxiety, depression, or boredom.

 (15) The precise effects of computers on the brain are complex and still not completely understood. (16) While computers can be invaluable tools for learning, there are limits to how much they can aid in cognitive development.
question_text: Which sentence should be added at the end of the first paragraph to best support the claim presented in the passage?
options: Overall, screen-based technology likely helps people develop certain cognitive skills at the expense of others.
People should carefully consider which computer games they choose to play.
Although there is hesitation to embrace screen-based technology, they are essential for success in today's world.
It is important for people to engage in activities that strengthen cognitive skills in multiple areas.

question_text: Which of the following would best follow and support sentence 4?
options: Computer games may also give people the skills to solve certain types of problems.
Of course, these benefits must be weighed against the harm that violent video games can have on children's psychological development.
In one study, people who played video games for 10 days were better able to shift their focus between visual images.
Some parents still forbid their children from playing video games because these games distract them from their schoolwork.

question_text:
Playing the game "Civilization," a game in which students build empires, ignited student learning in history and was linked with higher history grades. 

 Where should the above sentence be added to best support the ideas in the third paragraph? (lines 6-9)
options: between sentences 6 and 7
between sentences 7 and 8
between sentences 8 and 9
at the end of the paragraph (after sentence 9)

question_text: Which of the following would best follow and support sentence 10?
options: The violent nature of some of these games may make people desensitized to violence.
In fact, playing these games does not help, and may even hinder, our ability to think deeply and creatively.
Speed reading classes do not necessarily enhance actual comprehension.
Intelligence is typically defined as the ability to acquire knowledge and skills.

passage:
(1) There is considerable scientific debate over the effects of screen-based technology on the brain. (2) In addition, there are political disagreements over how much regulation should be applied to such media.

 (3 ) In general, computer usage seems to be most positively associated with improvements related to quick and basic information processing. question_text: Which sentence is irrelevant to the argument presented in the passage and should be deleted?
options: Sentence 1
Sentence 2
Sentence 3
Sentence 4

passage:
(1) There is considerable scientific debate over the effects of screen-based technology on the brain. (2) In addition, there are political disagreements over how much regulation should be applied to such media.

 (3 ) In general, computer usage seems to be most positively associated with improvements related to quick and basic information processing. (4) For example, people who play certain computer games are often better at performing tasks that require processing visual information quickly. (5) These games also help people develop improved reaction times and a better ability to shift focus between tasks.

 (6) Computer use can also improve our ability to learn. (7) For example, playing certain educational video games can increase students' interest in certain subjects. (8) Students also learn better when they are actively engaged in a task. (9) When they play math games online as part of their studying, they are more likely to master the skills they learn in school.

 (10) However, people should not conclude that playing computer games makes people smarter. (11) In addition, improved skills in one area are not transferable to improvements in other areas. (12) For example, improved visual-spatial skills will not make someone better at math. (13) Not only does computer use not make you "smarter" in the most fundamental sense, but excessive computer use can also reduce cortical thickness of the brain and have impaired cognitive functioning. (14) Computer addiction is often caused by anxiety, depression, or boredom.

 (15) The precise effects of computers on the brain are complex and still not completely understood. (16) While computers can be invaluable tools for learning, there are limits to how much they can aid in cognitive development.
